title: How to Pack Your Purse

steps.headline: Pack your wallet.
steps.description: Choose a wallet that has enough pockets for your bank card, credit cards, etc. Make sure the wallet also fits into your purse. Also, keep an identification in your wallet in case the wallet is lost or stolen.

steps.headline: Pack any makeup that you use daily for quick fixes.
steps.description: Also pack a mirror, hair bands, bobby pins, small hairbrush or comb, and a nail file.

steps.headline: Have tampons or sanitary pads in your purse.
steps.description: You don't want to be surprised and unprepared, and you may need to lend supplies to someone else. Some emergency Advil, Tylenol or other Ibuprofen type medication can be useful, too.

steps.headline: Pack your cell phone, and a charger if needed.
steps.description: You can also purchase extra batteries and keep them charged so they can be switched throughout the day.

steps.headline: Have your keys with you, even if you don't think you will use them.
steps.description: It's better to have them and not use them than to be locked out of the house or having to call for help.

steps.headline: Have a pen and a notepad, these are very helpful.
steps.description: You may need to write down a phone number, a schedule change, or an important reminder.

steps.headline: Be sure to pack tissues.
steps.description: A runny nose can be a pain (not to mention embarrassing!) And you may visit a poorly equipped public facility.

steps.headline: Have an emergency cash.
steps.description: A $10 bill and several quarters (or the equivalent in your local currency) in case you forget money or are short of change.

steps.headline: Remember first-aid.
steps.description: Even if you think it's unnecessary, you never know when you'll need a band-aid or a small tube of anti-bacterial ointment.

steps.headline: Pack musical entertainment.
steps.description: In case you get bored or have nothing to do have a music player of some sort so you can listen or sing along to music anytime anywhere.

steps.headline: If you're a DIY (Do It Yourself) sort of person, have in your purse a needle and thread.
steps.description: This way, you can temporarily fix a ripped shirt or shorts.

steps.headline: Keep track for a week or two of everything that you feel you need.
steps.description: Make a list of it, and be sure to put these items in your purse, along with some emergency items as well.

tyn: A purse that is small as possible, but fits all of your things
glasses, glasses case, and lens cleaner
bobby pins, pony tails, and headbands
nail file, nail polish, nail polish remover, etc.
text: Pack your wallet. Choose a wallet that has enough pockets for your bank card, credit cards, etc. Make sure the wallet also fits into your purse. Also, keep an identification in your wallet in case the wallet is lost or stolen. Pack any makeup that you use daily for quick fixes. Also pack a mirror, hair bands, bobby pins, small hairbrush or comb, and a nail file. Have tampons or sanitary pads in your purse. You don't want to be surprised and unprepared, and you may need to lend supplies to someone else. Some emergency Advil, Tylenol or other Ibuprofen type medication can be useful, too. Pack your cell phone, and a charger if needed. You can also purchase extra batteries and keep them charged so they can be switched throughout the day. Have your keys with you, even if you don't think you will use them. It's better to have them and not use them than to be locked out of the house or having to call for help. Have a pen and a notepad, these are very helpful. You may need to write down a phone number, a schedule change, or an important reminder. Be sure to pack tissues. A runny nose can be a pain (not to mention embarrassing!) And you may visit a poorly equipped public facility. Have an emergency cash. A $10 bill and several quarters (or the equivalent in your local currency) in case you forget money or are short of change. Remember first-aid. Even if you think it's unnecessary, you never know when you'll need a band-aid or a small tube of anti-bacterial ointment. Pack musical entertainment. In case you get bored or have nothing to do have a music player of some sort so you can listen or sing along to music anytime anywhere. If you're a DIY (Do It Yourself) sort of person, have in your purse a needle and thread. This way, you can temporarily fix a ripped shirt or shorts. Keep track for a week or two of everything that you feel you need. Make a list of it, and be sure to put these items in your purse, along with some emergency items as well.
sentences: Pack your wallet.
Choose a wallet that has enough pockets for your bank card, credit cards, etc.
Make sure the wallet also fits into your purse.
Also, keep an identification in your wallet in case the wallet is lost or stolen.
Pack any makeup that you use daily for quick fixes.
Also pack a mirror, hair bands, bobby pins, small hairbrush or comb, and a nail file.
Have tampons or sanitary pads in your purse.
You don't want to be surprised and unprepared, and you may need to lend supplies to someone else.
Some emergency Advil, Tylenol or other Ibuprofen type medication can be useful, too.
Pack your cell phone, and a charger if needed.
You can also purchase extra batteries and keep them charged so they can be switched throughout the day.
Have your keys with you, even if you don't think you will use them.
It's better to have them and not use them than to be locked out of the house or having to call for help.
Have a pen and a notepad, these are very helpful.
You may need to write down a phone number, a schedule change, or an important reminder.
Be sure to pack tissues.
A runny nose can be a pain (not to mention embarrassing!)
And you may visit a poorly equipped public facility.
Have an emergency cash.
A $10 bill and several quarters (or the equivalent in your local currency) in case you forget money or are short of change.
Remember first-aid.
Even if you think it's unnecessary, you never know when you'll need a band-aid or a small tube of anti-bacterial ointment.
Pack musical entertainment.
In case you get bored or have nothing to do have a music player of some sort so you can listen or sing along to music anytime anywhere.
If you're a DIY (Do It Yourself) sort of person, have in your purse a needle and thread.
This way, you can temporarily fix a ripped shirt or shorts.
Keep track for a week or two of everything that you feel you need.
Make a list of it, and be sure to put these items in your purse, along with some emergency items as well.
